titleStmt.title: My own visits and distributions and [the bearer]
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: It is possible that this manuscript was written as early as 1863, when Whitman began visiting soldiers in Washington, D.C.'s hospitals and wrote about his experiences in such pieces as "The Great Army of the Sick" and "Our Wounded and Sick Soldiers: Visits Among Army Hospitals," published in the New York Times on 26 February 1863 and 11 December 1864, respectively. However, the manuscript more likely dates to late 1873 or early 1874, as much of the material from the four leaves appears either verbatim or in slightly revised form in the fourth paper of Whitman's "'Tis But Ten Years Since" series, published in the New York Weekly Graphic on 21 Feburary 1874.
The following are responsible for particular readings or for changes to this file, as noted: Elizabeth Lorang Ashley Lawson Tim Jackson

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: My Visits and Distributions; The bearer, Mr. Walt Whitman
bibl.orgName: The Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature, New York Public Library
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

div2.p: For someseven or eight weeks past I have spent much of my timeon an average, perhaps, ( a couple of hours almost every day or evening, ) as a self‑appointed Soldierâ€™s Missionary, togoing about among these sick and dying men. I have not been to quite a number any thing like all, nor even half these establishments— the Hospitals— that, to do effectually, would be hardlyalmost impossible for one personvisitor. I have been to five or six— a good deal to the Campbell and Armory Square Hospitals, and a littleoccasionalyoccasionally to that at the Patent Office (now nearly broken up)—and once or twice to the 8th street and H. street hospitals, &c. At aAll timesEvery where I of course findhave found most powerful, and pathetic requirem though generallygenerally mute, calls upon one's sympathymy pocket, for some form of contribution, or some good office. Every EveryEach case has its peculiarities, needing something—needs some new adaptation.

And I have learnt to adapt myself therefore——learnt a good deal of hospital wisdom is required,and (one soon gets it) Some of the poor young men away from home the first time in their lives hunger and thirst for kindness, for affection, above all things. This of course goes a great ways;only will reach some of the cases: (many of the sick are mere boys.) ¶ I have distributed quite a large sum of money, contributed to for that purpose by noble persons in Brooklyn, New York, (chiefly through Moses Lane, Chief Engineer, Water Works. there.) and othe ¶ I provide myself with a quantity of bright new ten‑cent and five‑cent bills, and whe give with small sums of, these, 15 ,or 20, cts, 25, or 30, and somoccasionally 50 cts. —oh!Oh, if the friends who have sent thesethis money could see the what pleasure they have diffused, and what little comforts they have brought, better than any gift

they they confer on on others, would themselves be repaid, a thousandand many, many fold. Then distribute a numbervariety of articles, literally too numerous to mention. I regularly carry a haversack with me on my visits. —and my coat has the biggest kind of pockets. Among the things mostI might mention generally marking my progress through a Ward, I may mention that I
I distribute paper, and envelopes, and stamps—oranges and apples, and preserves and jellies—pickles—candies, (especially horehound)—tobacco, in small plugs——blackberry syrup, brandy, a large quantity of reading matter —over and over again——a few pocket diaries and Almanacks for 1863——a stack of old magazines and of the morning or evening papers of the day—and always of course my own personal talk, soothing, cheering up, and friendly comforting, generallyto each case according to its kind.

I buy tobacco by the pound, and cut it up in small plugs. Then I bought the other day bought a box of oranges. Every thing at retail is very dear here in Washington, (and wholesale too for that matter.)

head.hi: Cases, for example.—as you walk through.—one from Connecticut.

div2.p: Would you not like to know,see for yourself, good dear reader, some special ones of the cases, for example among the hundreds I have met with? Look downEnter with me this long Ward, with —loodlook down its rows of cots, with their occupants, on stretching downaway each side, andwith the wide open aisle inthrough the middle. Every one of these casescots has its history—every one—every case is a tragic poem, an epic, a romance, a pensive and absorbing book, if it were only written.

div1.p: The bearer, Mr. Walt Whitman, of Brooklyn, N.Y. is recommended to me byfrom the most distinguished sources. He desires employment as a clerk in the departments—or in any way in which he can be serviceable to the government. I commend him to the favorable consideration of any of the heads of departments who may need his services.
